reviewText: This was the movie way back in 1967 which inspired me to become a teacher.  I taught from 1968 til 2004.  I'm now retired.  I recently watched the new movie.  Sidney Poitier is an amazing actor...even in the latest To Sir With Love.  I've watched it over and over again over the years and never stop enjoying it.  It keeps reminding me why I became a teacher... the best job in the world, even though I also had some really tough kids some years.
summary: My favourite movie even after these years!

reviewText: Sidney Poitier, reprises his legendary role as Mark Thackeray, from "To Sir With Love". A great movie and a great title song, sung by Lulu. This time he takes a position in the United states of America, and learns new skills, as well as things about himself. Most sequels, do not live up to the original, but, this one does, in style.

reviewText: Great continuation of the original. It shows how much the lesson behind the first film is still applicable today. I have shown both to my middle school students in the past and once they got the hang of the English slang they were riveted (I taught students who were very much like the classes in both films).

reviewText: It just loses it when they send Mark Thackery to Chicago after retiring in London to work his magic on an inner city school in America. Doesn't live up to the classy act in the original. Good enough for TV but not the the big screen. There were a couple of contradictions... the character was from British Guyana not Chicago but the sequel is worth seeing for fans.
summary: A sequel that could have been better

reviewText: The DVD was one of the strangest ones I've ever seen.  There was NO menu at all. The movie simply started and ended.  You had to use your DVD player's options to determine the actual length (I didn't see it on the packaging).  The quality of the movie was fine.  Full-screen was expected since it was a made-for-TV movie.I had forgotten much of the story since I had not seen the movie in years but it was still AWESOME!  In some ways, it's even better than the original.  Different kids, different culture, but same basic solution - show the kids respect and insist on respect from them!  The depth of development of the kids was a bit better here than the original which is a bit surprising since the story itself was shorter.It was, in many ways, a typical Sidney Poitier movie - good drama without resorting to a lot of unnecessary violence.  Yes, there was some scuffling and even a gang fight and some shooting (no one was hit) but the impact was the drama and acting.It's a perfect extension of the original movie and the touch of the two "kids" from the original appearing at Mr. Thackery's retirement dinner was a very touching moment.  I cried when "Miss Peg" (Lulu) sang the original theme.There is only one question - why did this take so long to appear in a DVD format?
Title: N/A

reviewText: The movie begins with scenes from the first movie - which helps remind us who people are - especially since some of those "kids" are now grown up and are teaching with "Sir." The reason why he travels to the States is a little shaky, but once he's there, the story picks up. It's an engaging movie, not as much as the first one, but it's still a good movie to watch. Sidney Poitier is excellent in this role.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I would have given this movie a 5-Star rating but I chose to give instead a 4-star rating. For me personally, "To Sir With Love", a story about "telling tales and biting nails" involving rowdy, misbehaved, and disrespectful students in a slum neighborhood in East End London, was more persuasive and more powerful than "To Sir With Love II" set in New York City. "To Sir With Love" has captured the very essence of humanity in the persona of Mr. Mark Thackeray and the "East End" students. The final school days scene, when the students honored their "Sir" with that powerful song (which was also the title) and showed him all their love and admiration for transforming all of them to responsible, mature, respectable and best of all LOVABLE and DECENT human beings, provided a very emotional moment not only for Mr. Thackeray and other members of the teaching staff.  This particular scene in the original movie moved me to tears. "To Sir With Love II" also dealt with this same subject matter, which gave me the chance to compare riotous and misbehaving students in London to those in New York City.  Although the students were transformed in the end, that transformation did not quite meet my expectations as did the original movie. And that comparison affected my decision as far as the rating is concerned. I did not like "To Sir With Love" ... As a matter of fact, I LOVE IT!!! I practically fell in love with Mr. Mark Thackeray ... and, of course, Sidney Poitier. And I LIKE "To Sir With Love II". In this day and age, teachers, professors, and all those involved in trying to educate immature and irresponsible students should emulate someone like the remarkable Mr. Mark Thackeray; In fact, all educational institutions should have a Mr. Thackeray in their faculty. Thank you for giving me this opportunity to rate this product.
summary: Rating To Sir With Love II
